questions.text: Injury at which of the following marked sites causes failure of dorsiflexion?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 3

 

The site marked as '3' in the x-ray given above is the neck of the fibula. Injury at this site causes failure of dorsiflexion (foot drop) due to injury to the common fibular nerve.

 

Neck of Fibula is the narrowed region just distal to the head of the fibula. The common fibular (peroneal) nerve winds around the neck of the fibula. This makes the nerve vulnerable at this site, and any injury or compression can affect nerve function.

 

Site 1 – Lateral epicondyle

 

Site 2 – Head of Fibula

 

Site 3 – Neck of Fibula

 

Site 4 – Tibia

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Site 1. Lateral Epicondyle: It is a prominent bony protrusion on the lateral side of the distal end of the humerus, which is the bone of the upper arm. "Tennis elbow" or lateral epicondylitis is a common condition associated with the lateral epicondyle. It's caused by overuse and inflammation of the tendons that attach to the lateral epicondyle, leading to pain and tenderness at the site.

 

Site 2 - Head of Fibula: It is the proximal, rounded end of the fibula, the smaller of the two leg bones. It's located just below the lateral aspect of the knee joint.

 

This is the location of the common fibular (peroneal) nerve, which wraps around the neck of the fibula. Injuries or fractures to the head of the fibula may damage this nerve, potentially leading to foot drop.

 

Site 4 - Tibia: It is also known as the shinbone, is the larger, medial, and anterior bone of the leg, located between the knee and the ankle. It is anteromedially placed in the leg and is palpable along its length. The tibia is a common site for fractures, especially the distal part, due to its subcutaneous position. The anterior surface of the tibia, known as the shin, is easily palpable and is often the site of contusions or "shin splints" in athletes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common fibular nerve's course around the neck of the fibula makes this area a hotspot for injuries leading to dorsiflexion failure, underlining the importance of protecting this area from trauma.

questions.text: Identify the enzyme from the following list that is classified as a "Suicide Enzyme." (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyclooxygenase

 

Explanation:

 

Cyclooxygenase is classified as a suicide enzyme because it can be irreversibly inhibited by aspirin through a mechanism-based inhibition process. In suicide inhibition, the enzyme itself participates in converting the inhibitor into a highly reactive form that permanently binds to and inactivates the enzyme. Aspirin acts as a suicide inhibitor of cyclooxygenase by covalently modifying a specific serine residue in the enzyme's active site through acetylation, which prevents access of the substrate to the catalytic site and results in permanent inactivation of the enzyme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lipoxygenase: While this enzyme also participates in the arachidonic acid pathway, it is not characterized as undergoing suicide inhibition by its substrates or known inhibitors.

 

Option C. Pyruvate Dehydrogenase: is regulated by phosphorylation and product inhibition, but it does not undergo suicide inactivation.

 

Option D. Thromboxane Synthase: This enzyme participates in the prostaglandin synthesis pathway but is not known to undergo suicide inhibition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Suicide inhibition involves the enzyme converting a substrate analog into a reactive species that irreversibly inhibits the enzyme itself—cyclooxygenase exemplifies this mechanism where aspirin covalently modifies the enzyme, permanently inactivating it.

choices.text: 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by same dose after 24 hours
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 1 week
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 24 hours and after a week
2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks

questions.text: What is the recommended amount of vitamin A dosage for a 2-year-old child diagnosed with keratomalacia? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks

 

The recommended treatment for a 2-year-old child diagnosed with keratomalacia involves high-dose vitamin A supplementation to rapidly replenish depleted stores and prevent further ocular damage. The specific dosage regimen is:

 

  1. 2,00,000 IU of vitamin A administered immediately.
  2. 2,00,000 IU administered again 24 hours later.
  3. 2,00,000 IU administered again after 2 weeks.

 

This regimen is designed to quickly correct vitamin A deficiency and provide sustained support to prevent recurrence and promote healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The suggested vitamin A dose for a 2-year-old child diagnosed with keratomalacia is 200,000 IU, administered promptly, then repeated with the same age-appropriate amount after 24 hours and again after a span of 2 weeks.

 

Dosage of Vitamin A as per age: -

 

  • <6 months – 50,000 IU orally
  • 6-12 months – 1,00,000 IU orally
  • above 12 months – 2,00,000 IU orally

questions.text: Which of these methods relies on behavioral sciences? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Management by objective

 

Management by objective (MBO) is a technique based on behavioral sciences. It was developed by Peter Drucker in the 1950s and emphasizes the importance of setting clear goals and objectives that are aligned with organizational goals, and then measuring progress towards achieving those objectives.

 

MBO is based on the idea that individuals are motivated by the achievement of goals and that they perform better when they know what is expected of them. The technique involves a participatory process where employees are involved in setting their own goals and objectives, which are then reviewed and evaluated by their managers. This approach is intended to improve communication and collaboration within organizations, and to help employees feel more engaged and motivated in their work.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decision making:  This can rely on both behavioral sciences and quantitative methods, but in the context of management and organizational processes, it often involves analytical and quantitative approaches.

 

Option B. Systems analysis:  This is a quantitative method used to understand and analyze complex systems and processes, often involving mathematical models and simulations.

 

Option C. Network analysis:  This is a quantitative method used to plan and control complex projects, involving techniques like PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) and CPM (Critical Path Method).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with easy fatiguability. The mother also complains that the child has increased hunger between meals, which is relieved after food. Liver examination revealed no glycogen. What enzyme is most likely deficient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycogen synthase

 

Glycogen synthase: This is the correct answer. Glycogen synthase is responsible for synthesizing glycogen from glucose. A deficiency in glycogen synthase would result in the inability to produce glycogen, which aligns with the liver examination findings of no glycogen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency (McArdle’s disease or glycogen storage disease type V) primarily affects skeletal muscle glycogen metabolism. Symptoms include muscle weakness, cramps, and exercise intolerance.

 

Option C. Debranching enzyme deficiency (Cori's disease or glycogen storage disease type III) presents with hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, and growth retardation. The liver would still contain glycogen, although with an abnormal structure.

 

Option D. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency (von Gierke's disease or glycogen storage disease type I) is characterized by severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hepatomegaly, Renomegaly. In this case, glycogen is present in the liver but cannot be broken down efficiently into glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen synthase is a key enzyme involved in glycogenesis, the process of synthesizing glycogen, which serves as a storage form of glucose in the liver and muscles. Glycogen synthase catalyzes the addition of glucose molecules to the growing glycogen chain by creating alpha-1,4-glycosidic linkages between glucose units. This enzyme is regulated by various factors, including insulin, which promotes glycogen synthesis by activating glycogen synthase.

 

Mutations or dysregulation of glycogen synthase can lead to Glycogen Storage Disease 0 (GSD 0), a disorder resulting from mutations in the GYS2 gene encoding liver glycogen synthase. C/f include fasting hypoglycemia, hunger between meals, hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), and other metabolic abnormalities due to impaired glycogen synthesis.

questions.text: Lignocaine is used in a loading dose for the treatment of arrhythmias. The loading dose of this drug depends upon which of the following factors? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Volume of distribution

 

The loading dose of a drug is calculated using the formula:

 

 

In the context of Lignocaine, which is administered intravenously (IV) for the treatment of arrhythmias, the bioavailability is 100% because the drug is delivered directly into the bloodstream. Therefore, bioavailability does not factor into the calculation when the drug is given IV. The critical factor influencing the loading dose in this scenario is the volume of distribution (Vd), which represents the extent to which the drug distributes into body tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clearance: Clearance relates to the maintenance dose rather than the loading dose. It reflects the body's efficiency in eliminating the drug.

 

Option C. Half-life: Half-life is important for determining dosing intervals and steady-state concentration but does not directly determine the loading dose.

 

Option D. Bioavailability: While bioavailability is included in the loading dose calculation, it is only a determining factor when the drug is not administered intravenously. In this case, where Lignocaine is given IV, bioavailability is 100% and thus does not influence the loading dose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The volume of distribution is the key factor that determines the loading dose of a drug, especially in intravenous administration where bioavailability is 100%

questions.text: Heavy chain disease associated with the presence of kappa light chains in the urine: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia.

 

Explanation: 

 

Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (also called lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma) is characterized by production of IgM monoclonal protein and is associated with the presence of kappa light chains. In this condition, light chain (kappa) is produced in the same quantity as heavy chain (mu), which contrasts with other heavy chain diseases where there is predominant production of heavy chain antibody. The disease presents as an M spike of IgM type and commonly manifests with hyper viscosity syndrome due to the large size of IgM molecules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mu chain disease - This is incorrect. Mu (μ) chain disease is a rare heavy chain disease associated with CLL rather than with the presence of kappa light chains in urine. It involves the production of abnormal μ heavy chains without associated light chains.

 

Option B. Sezary disease - This is incorrect. Sezary syndrome is not a heavy chain disease but a variant of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma characterized by erythroderma, lymphadenopathy, and neoplastic T cells (Sezary cells) with cerebriform nuclei in the blood.

 

Option C. Franklin disease - This is incorrect. Franklin disease (gamma heavy chain disease) is characterized by the production of gamma (γ) heavy chains without associated light chains. It presents with fever, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, but not specifically with kappa light chains in urine.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is distinguished from other heavy chain diseases by the production of intact IgM molecules with balanced synthesis of heavy and light chains (including kappa light chains), often leading to hyper viscosity syndrome due to high levels of the large IgM protein.

questions.text: Xerophthalmia is considered a public health problem if the prevalence of bitot's spot is more than: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.8%

 

Explanation:

 

One of the criteria for considering xerophthalmia as a public health problem is if the prevalence of bitot's spots (a sign of vitamin A deficiency) is more than 0.5% in the population. The specifically asks about the prevalence of bitot's spots, and the option closest to 0.5% is 0.8%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prevalence criteria for determining the Xerophthalmia problem in a community: (Preschool children 6 months- 6 years).

questions.text: Identify the type of wound from the image: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Defense wounds

 

The image shows multiple wounds on the hand, indicative of defense wounds. These are injuries received by a victim of an attack while trying to defend against the assailant.

 

Defense wounds are typically found on the hands and forearms, showing deep incised or blunt force injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antemortem wound: Wounds inflicted before death, characterized by bleeding, clot formation, and tissue reaction. Defense wounds are a type of antemortem wound, but the specific context here is self-defense.

 

Option C. Postmortem wound: Wounds inflicted after death, characterized by the absence of vital reactions such as bleeding and clotting.

 

Option D. Hesitation cuts: Multiple, small, superficial incised wounds made by a person during a suicide attempt while hesitating to make a final decisive cut.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is accumulated in joint in the mucopolysaccharidosis associated with Natowicz disease? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyaluronic acid

 

Natowicz disease (MPS type IX) is characterized by:

 

  • Enzyme deficiency: Hyaluronidase
  • Accumulated substance: Hyaluronic acid
  • Clinical features include joint pain and short stature
  • This is a rare form of mucopolysaccharidosis
  • The condition results from inability to break down hyaluronic acid due to hyaluronidase deficiency

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermatan sulfate: Incorrect

 

  • Because dermatan sulfate accumulation is seen in MPS types I, II and VI
  • Its accumulation typically leads to cardiovascular manifestations like atherosclerosis

 

Option B. Heparan sulfate: Incorrect

 

  • Because heparan sulfate accumulation is seen in MPS types I, II and III
  • Its accumulation typically leads to mental retardation
  • Present on cell surfaces and has a role in cell-cell adhesion

 

Option C. Keratan sulfate: Incorrect

 

  • Because keratan sulfate accumulation is seen in MPS type IV
  • It is unique among GAGs as it does not contain uronic acid
  • Responsible for corneal transparency
  • Present in cornea and connective tissue

 

Educational Objective:

 

Natowicz disease (MPS type IX) is characterized by hyaluronidase deficiency leading to accumulation of hyaluronic acid in joints, causing joint pain and short stature.

questions.text: Duroziez’s sign is seen in? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aortic Regurgitation

 

Explanation:

 

Duroziez's sign is a clinical finding specifically associated with aortic regurgitation. This sign consists of a to-and-fro murmur heard over the femoral artery when it is lightly compressed with a stethoscope. This peripheral manifestation occurs because of the wide pulse pressure and rapid diastolic runoff characteristic of significant aortic regurgitation. Duroziez's sign appears alongside other peripheral signs of aortic regurgitation in the clinical examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tricuspid Regurgitation: Tricuspid regurgitation is characterized by prominent c-v waves in the jugular venous pulse, a systolic murmur along the left sternal border that increases with inspiration (Carvallo's sign), and signs of right heart failure including hepatomegaly, ascites, and edema. Duroziez's sign, which involves the femoral artery, is not associated with tricuspid regurgitation.

 

Option C. Mitral Stenosis: Mitral stenosis presents with a diastolic rumbling murmur at the apex, an opening snap, pulmonary congestion, and potential atrial fibrillation. The key signs include prominent waves in the jugular venous pulse if in sinus rhythm and hemoptysis in some cases. Duroziez's sign is not characteristic of mitral stenosis.

 

Option D. Pericardial Effusion: Pericardial effusion is associated with muffled heart sounds, increased cardiac dullness to percussion, electrical alternans on ECG in large effusions, and pulsus paradoxus. Duroziez's sign involves arterial auscultation and is not related to pericardial effusion.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Duroziez's sign (to-and-fro murmur heard over the compressed femoral artery) is a specific peripheral finding in aortic regurgitation, occurring alongside other peripheral signs including Corrigan's water-hammer pulse, capillary pulsations (Quincke's sign), and Traube's sign (pistol-shot sound over femoral arteries).

questions.text: A 50-year-old emmetropic man is no longer able to read with the presbyopic glasses he had made 5 years ago. The power of his new prescription glasses should be:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. +2D

 

Since, the question asks for the new prescription, the answer should be +2.00D.

 

Had the question asked us to estimate the power of his old glasses, it would have been +1.5 DS.

 

The power of the prescription glasses for a 50-year-old man should be +2D.

 

This condition of falling near vision due to age-related decrease in the amplitude of accommodation or increase in punctum proximum is called presbyopia.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Emmetropic Man: The patient has no refractive error for distance vision but is experiencing difficulty with near vision due to presbyopia.
  • Current Glasses: If the patient had glasses made 5 years ago (when he was around 45), those glasses were likely around +1.5 D.
  • New Prescription: As presbyopia progresses, the strength of the glasses needs to be increased to +2.0 D to accommodate the further decline in near vision.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Roughly, the power of prescription glasses age-wise is as follows:

questions.text: A female presents to OPD with 6 weeks of amenorrhea complaints of bleeding per vagina and mild abdominal pain. The urine pregnancy test is positive and hCG level is 2800 IU/L. On investigation, mass is seen on the left adnexa measuring 3 x 2 cm. She is hemodynamically stable. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single-dose methotrexate injection

 

The clinical scenario presented indicates an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. The patient is hemodynamically stable, and the hCG level is 2800 IU/L with an adnexal mass measuring 3 x 2 cm. These findings meet the criteria for medical management of an ectopic pregnancy with methotrexate. Single-dose methotrexate injection is an appropriate treatment choice for an unruptured ectopic pregnancy when the patient is stable, has no significant symptoms, and the gestational sac is less than 3.5 cm in size without visible cardiac activity. Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist that inhibits DNA synthesis and cell replication, effectively treating the ectopic pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral methotrexate: Oral methotrexate is not a standard treatment protocol for ectopic pregnancy. Methotrexate for ectopic pregnancy is typically administered via injection to ensure proper dosage and effectiveness.

 

Option C. Serial methotrexate + leucovorin rescue: This multidose protocol is used for ectopic pregnancies with higher hCG levels or when the single-dose protocol is contraindicated or has failed. However, it is more complex and involves multiple injections and monitoring.

 

Option D. Salpingectomy: Surgical management, such as salpingectomy, is indicated for ectopic pregnancies with significant pain, adnexal masses larger than 35 mm, visible fetal heartbeat, or serum hCG levels of 5000 IU/L or more. In this case, the patient’s condition does not meet these criteria, making surgery unnecessary.

 

Management of Unruptured Ectopic

 

 

Surgical Management in Unruptured Ectopic –

 

Indicated in:

 

  1. an ectopic pregnancy and significant pain
  2. an ectopic pregnancy with an adnexal mass of 35 mm or larger
  3. an ectopic pregnancy with a fetal heartbeat visible on an ultrasound scan
  4. an ectopic pregnancy and a serum hCG level of 5,000 IU/L or more

 

 Laparoscopy is preferred

 

  1. SALPINGECTOMY: Preferred if:
    • Extensive tubal involvement/ damage
    • Recurrent ectopic pregnancy in the same tube
    • Completed family
    • Ectopic at the site of a previous tubal sterilization
  2. SALPINGOSTOMY: (Linear incision on the antimesenteric border with removal of products of conception) Done if a woman wants to conceive in the future.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy in a hemodynamically stable patient with an hCG level less than 5000 IU/L and an adnexal mass smaller than 3.5 cm is typically treated with a single-dose methotrexate injection.

questions.text: What immunization coverage percentage is required by the WHO for the eradication of measles? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 96% 

 

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) stipulates that to achieve the complete elimination of measles, an immunization coverage of at least 96% among children under the age of 1 is necessary. 
  • This high percentage is critical because measles is highly contagious. Such a high coverage rate ensures herd immunity, significantly reducing the chances of measles transmission and protecting those who are not immune.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To eradicate measles, the WHO recommends an immunization coverage of 96% among children under the age of 1, emphasizing the need for near-universal coverage to achieve herd immunity and effectively control the disease.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image, which developed after 3 days of catheterization. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fournier gangrene 

 

This is a serious bacterial infection characterized by necrotizing fasciitis affecting the perineal, genital, or perianal regions. It often presents with rapid onset, pain, swelling, and crepitus due to gas formation, and is associated with high morbidity and mortality rates. The infection can spread quickly, and early surgical intervention is critical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gas gangrene: Also known as clostridial myonecrosis, gas gangrene is caused by infection with Clostridium species and is characterized by sudden, severe pain, swelling, and production of gas, which can be palpable as crepitus

 

Option C. Wet gangrene: This form of gangrene arises when the blood flow to an area is lost, and a bacterial infection develops. It typically affects extremities and is associated with swelling, blistering, and a wet appearance due to pus.

 

Option D. Scrotal hematoma: This is a collection of blood within the scrotal sac but does not involve an infection. It may occur after trauma or surgery. While it can cause swelling and discoloration, it does not present with the same level of systemic illness seen in gangrenous conditions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fournier gangrene is a urological emergency that involves necrotizing fasciitis of the external genitalia and requires prompt surgical debridement along with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

questions.text: MTP for failure of contraception can be done till: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20 weeks

 

The correct answer is 20 weeks. According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Amendment Act of 2021, termination of pregnancy for the failure of contraception can be performed up to 20 weeks. The Act outlines specific requirements for performing an MTP at different stages of pregnancy:

 

  1. Up to 20 weeks: MTP can be done for various reasons, including maternal health risks, fetal anomalies, pregnancy resulting from rape, or failure of contraception. Only one doctor's opinion is required for termination within this period.
  2. 20 to 24 weeks: Requires the opinion of two doctors. The reasons include threats to maternal health, fetal anomalies, pregnancy resulting from rape, pregnancies in minors, changes in marital status (e.g., becoming a widow or divorce), humanitarian grounds (e.g., war, natural disasters), or if the woman is disabled.
  3. Beyond 24 weeks: Termination is only permitted for substantial fetal malformations and requires approval from a medical board due to the viability of the fetus at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the MTP Amendment Act of 2021, MTP for failure of contraception can be performed up to 20 weeks with the opinion of one doctor.

choices.text: Focal area of decreased air entry will be suggestive of foreign body
In complete obstruction, ball and valve mechanism causes hyperinflation
The child has developed acute laryngotracheobronchitis

questions.text: A previously healthy child presented with acute-onset dyspnea. A chest X-ray shows unilateral hyperinflation of the lungs. What is true for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Focal area of decreased air entry will be suggestive of foreign body

 

The clinical presentation suggests the presence of a foreign body in the airway, most likely in the bronchi, causing incomplete airway obstruction. This would be evident on auscultation as a focal area of decreased air entry. This condition is more common in children under 4 years old, and food items are the most common foreign bodies. Non-irritating types, such as plastic, glass, or metallic foreign bodies, and irritating types, such as vegetables, peanuts, beans, and seeds, are frequently encountered. The right bronchus is more susceptible to foreign body impaction because it is wider and more in line with the tracheal lumen.

 

Evaluation:

 

  • A plain X-ray chest in posteroanterior and lateral views (expiratory films are useful) is performed to evaluate a foreign body in the airway.
  • The X-ray may show the radio-opaque foreign body's size, shape, and location, lobar or segmental atelectasis in complete airway obstruction, or hyperinflation or obstructive emphysema of the affected area due to the ball valve mechanism.

 

Management:

 

  • The management of foreign body airway depends on the location of the foreign body.
  • A laryngeal foreign body can be treated with the Heimlich maneuver, and if it fails, cricothyrotomy or emergency tracheostomy should be performed.
  • Foreign bodies in the trachea and bronchi can be removed using a rigid bronchoscope after adequate hydration and emptying of the stomach.
  • Appropriate antibiotics are given to prevent secondary infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flexible bronchoscopy used for removal: Rigid bronchoscopy is preferred over flexible bronchoscopy for the removal of foreign bodies in the trachea and bronchi because it allows better visualization and manipulation.

 

Option C. In complete obstruction, ball and valve mechanism causes hyperinflation: Incomplete obstruction, not complete obstruction, is associated with the ball valve mechanism, which causes hyperinflation by allowing air to enter but not leave the affected area.

 

Option D. The child has developed acute laryngotracheobronchitis: Laryngotracheobronchitis, or croup, is caused by the parainfluenza virus. It commonly affects children aged 6 months to 3 years and presents with a barking cough, biphasic stridor, and low-grade fever. The chest X-ray shows a narrowing of the subglottic region known as the steeple sign, which is not consistent with the presented case of foreign body aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute-onset dyspnea with unilateral hyperinflation on chest X-ray, a focal area of decreased air entry is suggestive of foreign body aspiration, which is more common in children under 4 years old.

choices.text: Not associated with rise in Creatinine

questions.text: Acute graft rejection in a kidney transplant patient is indicated by: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Any rise in creatinine

 

In modern transplant medicine, acute graft rejection often presents subtly due to powerful immunosuppression regimens. The most common presentation of acute rejection in current clinical practice is an asymptomatic rise in serum creatinine. According to the definition, there should be at least a 25% increase in serum creatinine to diagnose acute rejection. However, in cases where antibody-mediated rejection (ABMR) is suspected, any rise in serum creatinine can lead to a diagnosis or at least a suspicion of acute rejection.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Creatinine raised by 5%: Incorrect because acute rejection is characterized by a rise in creatinine levels. Normal creatinine would not indicate rejection.

 

Option C. Creatinine raised by 10%: While this would also indicate rejection, the question asks for the earliest indicator, and any rise in creatinine (including 5%) should raise suspicion.

 

Option D. Not associated with rise in Creatinine: Incorrect because there is a clear association between creatinine rises and acute rejection. This is one of the most reliable indicators of rejection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute graft rejection in kidney transplant patients typically presents with asymptomatic elevation in serum creatinine. Traditional symptoms like fever and graft tenderness are less common due to current immunosuppression protocols. Any rise in creatinine should prompt consideration of acute rejection.

questions.text: A patient with a malignancy is undergoing chemotherapy. The platelet counts were reduced after the previous cycle of chemotherapy. Which of the following drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oprelvekin (IL-11)

 

Oprelvekin (IL-11) is a recombinant form of interleukin-11, which is used to prevent severe thrombocytopenia and reduce the need for platelet transfusions following myelosuppressive chemotherapy in patients with non-myeloid malignancies. Oprelvekin works by stimulating the proliferation and maturation of megakaryocytes, the precursor cells to platelets, thereby increasing platelet counts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Filgrastim: Filgrastim is a granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF), used in treatment of neutropenia post-chemotherapy.

 

Option C. Erythropoietin: Erythropoietin like Darbepoetin is indicated in Anemia due to chronic kidney disease and bone marrow suppression.

 

Option D. Amifostine: Amifostine is indicated in cisplatin induced nephrotoxicity

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oprelvekin (IL-11) is the drug of choice for managing chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia by increasing platelet counts, thereby reducing the need for platelet transfusions in patients undergoing myelosuppressive chemotherapy.

questions.text: Identify the modality shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retrograde pyelogram

 

The X-ray shows characteristics of retrograde pyelogram:

 

  • Contrast visible in only one ureter and renal pelvis
  • Presence of catheter visible (placed via cystoscopy)
  • No nephrogram phase visible (kidney shadow not seen)
  • Shows renal pelvis in claw-like appearance
  • Performed by injecting contrast directly into ureter via cystoscopy
  • Used when IVU fails or in non-functioning kidney

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IVU: Incorrect as IVU shows bilateral ureter and renal system, includes nephrogram phase, and no catheter is visible

 

 

Option C. Ureteric stent: Incorrect as a stent would appear as a distinct radio-opaque tube with curved ends (double-J appearance), without contrast
 

 

Option D. Nephrostomy tube: Incorrect as nephrostomy tube enters directly through flank into kidney, not via ureter

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Retrograde Pyelogram (RGP) is a contrast study performed via cystoscopy, allowing visualization of one-sided ureters and renal pelvis. It is used to diagnose ureteric strictures, stones, and tumors.

questions.text: A 60-year-old farmer reports symptoms of fever, body pain, and a cough. A physical examination reveals a black lesion as depicted in the accompanying image. Laboratory tests confirm the presence of IgM antibodies indicative of Scrub Typhus infection. What treatment approach would be most advisable in this case? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Doxycycline alone

 

Explanation:

 

  • This black lesion is Eschar and this is the acute case of Scrub Typhus.
  • Causative organism - Rickettsia tsutsugamushi; Vector - Mite
  • The preferred approach depends on the severity of the condition and individual patient considerations.

 

Option A. Doxycycline Alone:

 

  1. Use: This is the first-line treatment for Scrub Typhus.
  2. Mechanism: Doxycycline works by inhibiting protein synthesis in bacteria, effectively controlling the infection.
  3. Why Prefer: It's highly effective and typically well-tolerated, making it suitable for most cases unless contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Doxycycline + Azithromycin: Used when there is co-infection with other pathogens that azithromycin can cover or when doxycycline alone isn't adequately effective.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone + Doxycycline: This combination might be used in more severe cases or when the patient has complications that might benefit from a broader antibiotic coverage.

 

Option D. Ceftriaxone Alone: While effective against many types of bacteria, it's not the targeted treatment for Scrub Typhus and generally not recommended unless other options are contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Doxycycline alone is usually sufficient and most advisable for uncomplicated Scrub Typhus. 
  • Combination therapies may be considered in specific clinical scenarios where co-infections or severe presentations are evident.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in a child presenting with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxoplasma

 

The presentation of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications is highly indicative of congenital toxoplasmosis. Toxoplasmosis is caused by the protozoan Toxoplasma gondii, which can infect the fetus during pregnancy if the mother acquires the infection. The classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes:

 

  1. Chorioretinitis
  2. Hydrocephalus
  3. Diffuse parenchymal calcifications

 

These parenchymal calcifications are distributed throughout the brain tissue, which is a key distinguishing feature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zika virus: Zika virus infections are primarily associated with microcephaly, calcifications in both the gray and white matter, and other severe brain malformations, not specifically with parenchymal calcifications along with hydrocephalus and chorioretinitis.

 

Option C. Rubella: Congenital rubella syndrome can lead to multiple defects, including hearing loss, heart defects, and cataracts. However, it is not typically associated with the triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications.

 

Option D. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Congenital CMV infection is commonly associated with periventricular calcifications rather than diffuse parenchymal calcifications. This means calcifications are found around the ventricles of the brain rather than throughout the parenchyma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications is characteristic of congenital toxoplasmosis.

choices.text: Part of kidney involved

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important determinant of malignant potential in the papillary type of renal tumor? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Size

 

The size of the tumor is the most important determinant of malignant potential in papillary renal tumors.

 

Renal tumors of the papillary type include:

 

  • Papillary adenoma of the kidney (</= 1.5 cm)
  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma (RCC) - greater than 1.5 cm

 

Small renal papillary growths are fairly common and are discovered by chance. One of the processes carried out during the evaluation of donor transplant kidneys is the ruling out of malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunohistology: While useful for diagnostic and subtyping purposes, it is not the primary determinant of malignant potential. It helps identify the type of cells involved and the presence of specific markers.

 

Option C. Cytogenetics: Provides information on genetic abnormalities and can predict aggressiveness but is secondary to size in determining malignant potential.

 

Option D. Part of kidney involved: Although the location can affect treatment approaches and outcomes, it does not primarily determine whether a tumor is malignant; size is more predictive of malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In papillary renal tumors, the size greater than 1.5 cm is the most critical determinant in assessing malignancy, outweighing factors like immunohistology, cytogenetics, and part of the kidney involved in terms of initial evaluation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient with early satiety, bleeding and on examination, patient has spleen palpable till umbilicus. WBC count is 85,000/mm³ with immature WBCs seen in the peripheral blood smear. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Myeloid Leukemia

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). The patient presents with massive splenomegaly, early satiety, bleeding, and a significantly elevated white blood cell (WBC) count of 85,000/mm³ with immature WBCs in the peripheral smear. These features are characteristic of CML, a type of leukemia where the bone marrow makes too many white blood cells. The presence of immature WBCs (a left shift) and massive splenomegaly are classic signs of CML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML): While AML also involves immature WBCs, it usually presents more acutely and with less pronounced splenomegaly.

 

Diagnosed if – Myeloid blast count >20%;  APL (t15:17); CBF (t8:21; t16:16 inversion 16)

 

Option C. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL): CLL typically presents with a high number of mature lymphocytes rather than immature WBCs.

 

Option D. Sickle cell anemia: This condition is unlikely in a 60-year-old due to autosplenectomy typically occurring by age 3-4, making splenomegaly in this age group highly unlikely. Moreover, the WBC count in sickle cell anemia is not usually elevated to this extent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CML should be suspected in patients presenting with massive splenomegaly, significantly elevated WBC count, and immature WBCs on peripheral smear. Recognizing these signs can prompt further diagnostic evaluation, including the detection of the Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL fusion gene).

 

CML ideally Diagnosed as – Blast count <20% + Philadelphia +ve + Left shift in PS (lots of immature WBC)

questions.text: The treatment of choice in acute sarcoidosis is? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prednisolone.

 

Explanation:

 

Corticosteroids are the first-line treatment for sarcoidosis. In the management of sarcoidosis, immunosuppression with corticosteroids (specifically prednisolone) is the established primary therapy. This is particularly important in acute disease presentations where symptom control and prevention of progression are needed.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclosporin: While cyclosporine is an immunosuppressive agent, it is not the first-line treatment for acute sarcoidosis. It may be considered in select cases where corticosteroids are contraindicated or ineffective.

 

Option C. Infliximab: Infliximab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor that may be used in refractory cases of sarcoidosis, but it is not the first-line treatment for acute sarcoidosis.

 

Option D. IV Immunoglobulins: Intravenous immunoglobulins are not indicated as a primary treatment modality for acute sarcoidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Corticosteroids (prednisolone) remain the first-line treatment for acute sarcoidosis requiring therapy, with alternative immunosuppressive agents considered for steroid-resistant or refractory cases.
